articles.headline: Apple’s Culture of Secrecy
articles.snippet: Under its chief executive and founder Steven P. Jobs, Apple has created a culture of secrecy that has served it well in many ways — from new products to the health of Mr. Jobs.
articles.abstract: Under its chief executive and founder Steven P. Jobs, Apple has created a culture of secrecy that has served it well in many ways — from new products to the health of Mr. Jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: “No one wants to die,” said Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs. “And yet death is the destination we all share. No one has ever escaped it.”

articles.headline: California Bars Restaurant Use of Trans Fats
articles.snippet: Under a new law, the fats long linked to health problems must be excised from restaurants and retail baked goods.
articles.abstract: Under a new law, the fats long linked to health problems must be excised from restaurants and retail baked goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  California, a national trendsetter in all matters edible, became the first state to ban trans fats in restaurants when Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed a bill Friday to phase out their use.

articles.headline: Weight Drives the Young to Adult Pills, Data Says
articles.snippet: A growing number of children are taking drugs for a wide range of chronic conditions related to childhood obesity.
articles.abstract: A growing number of children are taking drugs for a wide range of chronic conditions related to childhood obesity.
articles.lead_paragraph: A growing number of American children are taking drugs for a wide range of chronic conditions related to childhood obesity, according to prescription data from three large organizations.

articles.headline: Danger Lurks When Shopping for Student Loans
articles.snippet: Comparison shopping for a private student loan -- unlike a mortgage or an auto loan -- may hurt your credit score.
articles.abstract: Comparison shopping for a private student loan -- unlike a mortgage or an auto loan -- may hurt your credit score.
articles.lead_paragraph: When college financial aid officers got into trouble last year for accepting gifts from lenders, the moral of the story was clear: You could easily overpay for your student loan by simply borrowing from a college’s recommended lender without first shopping around.

articles.headline: Flush With Cash, More Asian Tourists Flock to Japan
articles.snippet: Once prohibitively expensive, Japan is suddenly drawing soaring numbers of Asian tourists — a sign of big economic changes in one of the world’s most dynamic regions.
articles.abstract: Once prohibitively expensive, Japan is suddenly drawing soaring numbers of Asian tourists — a sign of big economic changes in one of the world’s most dynamic regions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHIRETOKO NATIONAL PARK, Japan  Once prohibitively expensive, Japan is suddenly drawing soaring numbers of Asian tourists who splurge at the nation’s department stores, lounge in its hot spring resorts or explore remote corners, like this stretch of pristine mountains and forests on Japan’s northernmost tip.

articles.headline: Plummeting Resale Values Lead Chrysler to End Leases
articles.snippet: Chrysler is getting out of the car leasing business, a move that comes amid falling resale values of trucks and S.U.V.’s that have cost automakers billions of dollars.
articles.abstract: Chrysler is getting out of the car leasing business, a move that comes amid falling resale values of trucks and S.U.V.’s that have cost automakers billions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Chrysler is getting out of the auto leasing business.

articles.headline: Drug Test a Success for Amgen
articles.snippet: The biotechnology company reported a successful trial for an experimental osteoporosis drug that reduced the risk of bone fractures in post-menopausal women.
articles.abstract: The biotechnology company reported a successful trial for an experimental osteoporosis drug that reduced the risk of bone fractures in post-menopausal women.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amgen’s experimental bone drug, widely considered to be crucial to the company’s future, has succeeded in its most important clinical trial, sending the company’s shares up sharply.

articles.headline: Power Rising, Taliban Besiege Pakistani Shiites
articles.snippet: In a strategic region of Pakistan, the Taliban have inflamed and exploited a long-running sectarian conflict.
articles.abstract: In a strategic region of Pakistan, the Taliban have inflamed and exploited a long-running sectarian conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  It was once known as the Parrot’s Beak, a strategic jut of Pakistan that the American-backed mujahedeen used to carry out raids on the Russians just over the border into Afghanistan. That was during the cold war.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: In Gas-Powered World, Ethanol Stirs Complaints
articles.snippet: A mutiny is growing against energy policies that heavily support and subsidize the blending of ethyl alcohol, or ethanol, into gasoline.
articles.abstract: A mutiny is growing against energy policies that heavily support and subsidize the blending of ethyl alcohol, or ethanol, into gasoline.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY  “Why Do You Put Alcohol in Your Tank?” demands a large sign outside one gas station here, which reassures drivers that it sells only “100% Gas.”

articles.headline: 4,000 U.S. Deaths, and a Handful of Images
articles.snippet: Some journalists say the American military is making a growing effort to control graphic war images from Iraq.
articles.abstract: Some journalists say the American military is making a growing effort to control graphic war images from Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The case of a freelance photographer in Iraq who was barred from covering the Marines after he posted photos on the Internet of several of them dead has underscored what some journalists say is a growing effort by the American military to control graphic images from the war.
articles.byline: By Michael Kamber and Tim Arango

articles.headline: A Shiite Militia in Baghdad Sees Its Power Wane
articles.snippet: The Mahdi Army has been profoundly weakened in a number of neighborhoods, in an important, if tentative, milestone for stability in Iraq.
articles.abstract: The Mahdi Army has been profoundly weakened in a number of neighborhoods, in an important, if tentative, milestone for stability in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The militia that was once the biggest defender of poor Shiites in Iraq, the Mahdi Army, has been profoundly weakened in a number of neighborhoods across Baghdad, in an important, if tentative, milestone for stability in Iraq.

articles.headline: Called to Help: 28 Years as a Lifeguard
articles.snippet: The idea that the job of a lifeguard is something straight from the TV show “Baywatch” could not be further from the truth.
articles.abstract: The idea that the job of a lifeguard is something straight from the TV show “Baywatch” could not be further from the truth.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN people hear I’m a lifeguard, the first thing they usually think of is the television show “Baywatch.” They ask me if I spend my day checking out women on the beach like the guys on the show. They ask me if real-life rescues always end as happily as they do on TV.
articles.byline: By JAMES BIRDSELL; as told to MATT VILLANO

articles.headline: Cocaine Sustains War in Rural Colombia
articles.snippet: Colombia’s four-decade war fueled by the drug trade is proving immune to American-financed efforts to stop it.
articles.abstract: Colombia’s four-decade war fueled by the drug trade is proving immune to American-financed efforts to stop it.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASTO, Colombia  Along with Colombia’s successes in fighting leftist rebels this year, cities like Medellín have staged remarkable recoveries. And in the upscale districts of Bogotá, the capital, it is almost possible to forget that the country remains mired in a devilishly complex four-decade-old war.

articles.headline: After Iowa Raid, Immigrants Fuel Labor Inquiries
articles.snippet: Following a raid at an Iowa meatpacking plant, immigrants have described pervasive labor violations that experts say could result in criminal charges.
articles.abstract: Following a raid at an Iowa meatpacking plant, immigrants have described pervasive labor violations that experts say could result in criminal charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: POSTVILLE, Iowa  When federal immigration agents raided the kosher meatpacking plant here in May and rounded up 389 illegal immigrants, they found more than 20 under-age workers, some as young as 13.

articles.headline: Agents Replaying a Hollywood Drama
articles.snippet: How the talent agency Endeavor, founded in 1995, goes about proving it has staying power offers a window onto the shifting landscape of talent brokering in Hollywood.
articles.abstract: How the talent agency Endeavor, founded in 1995, goes about proving it has staying power offers a window onto the shifting landscape of talent brokering in Hollywood.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

articles.headline: Black Radio on Obama Is Left’s Answer to Limbaugh
articles.snippet: Black radio hosts’ efforts to support Barack Obama could help increase voter turnout in a vital part of his coalition.
articles.abstract: Black radio hosts’ efforts to support Barack Obama could help increase voter turnout in a vital part of his coalition.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA  Warren Ballentine, one of black talk radio’s new stars, was on a tear against Senator John McCain as he broadcast from the Greenbriar Mall here last week, blithely dismissing Mr. McCain’s kind words about Senator Barack Obama at the recent N.A.A.C.P. national convention.

articles.headline: How One Borrower Beat the Foreclosure Machine
articles.snippet: Who owns the note on a home when it is forced into foreclosure, often a murky question, is among the factors that have helped homeowners facing foreclosures to fight back.
articles.abstract: Who owns the note on a home when it is forced into foreclosure, often a murky question, is among the factors that have helped homeowners facing foreclosures to fight back.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAMIE RUTH PALMER isn’t a celebrity. People magazine doesn’t chronicle her every move. The paparazzi don’t wait for a photo op outside of the modest Atlanta home where she has lived since 1987.

articles.headline: Can Hank Paulson Defuse This Crisis?
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., preached against “excessive regulation.” But he now finds himself leading an expansive government intervention.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., preached against “excessive regulation.” But he now finds himself leading an expansive government intervention.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF Henry M. Paulson Jr. hadn’t left Wall Street for Washington to become Treasury secretary in 2006, he would still be making tens of millions of dollars a year as the chairman of Goldman Sachs. He would be comfortably zipping around the globe on a corporate jet. He would be presiding over the only big Wall Street firm that hasn’t lost billions on bad debt.
articles.byline: By Steven R. Weisman and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Steven Spielberg’s Director’s Cut
articles.snippet: Steven Spielberg’s recently announced partnership with an Indian group to form a new movie company contains an element of shock: that Hollywood could not come up with a rich enough deal for him.
articles.abstract: Steven Spielberg’s recently announced partnership with an Indian group to form a new movie company contains an element of shock: that Hollywood could not come up with a rich enough deal for him.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOW did Hollywood lose Steven Spielberg?

articles.headline: As Doctors Cater to Looks, Skin Patients Wait
articles.snippet: Dermatology is becoming a two-tier business in which higher-paying customers are often pampered.
articles.abstract: Dermatology is becoming a two-tier business in which higher-paying customers are often pampered.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Donald Richey, a dermatologist in Chico, Calif., has two office telephone numbers: calls to the number for patients seeking an appointment for skin conditions like acne and psoriasis often go straight to voice mail, but a full-time staff member fields calls on the dedicated line for cosmetic patients seeking beauty treatments like Botox.

articles.headline: Worried Banks Sharply Reduce Business Loans
articles.snippet: Struggling to recover from multibillion-dollar losses, banks are curtailing loans even to healthy businesses.
articles.abstract: Struggling to recover from multibillion-dollar losses, banks are curtailing loans even to healthy businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banks struggling to recover from multibillion-dollar losses on real estate are curtailing loans to American businesses, depriving even healthy companies of money for expansion and hiring.

articles.headline: Leftover Ad Space? Exchanges Handle the Remnants
articles.snippet: Because there are usually lower fees, buying off exchanges tends to be cheaper -- though more labor-intensive -- than buying through networks.
articles.abstract: Because there are usually lower fees, buying off exchanges tends to be cheaper -- though more labor-intensive -- than buying through networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joe Zawadzki’s traders spend their days in front of two computer screens, feeding their systems with data and trying to perfect their trading algorithms.

articles.headline: Democracy Group Gives Donors Access to McCain
articles.snippet: The International Republican Institute is in many ways at odds with John McCain’s political outsider image.
articles.abstract: The International Republican Institute is in many ways at odds with John McCain’s political outsider image.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Senator John McCain waited to speak at the annual awards dinner of the International Republican Institute, a democracy-building group he has led for 15 years, lobbyists and business executives dominated the stage at a Washington hotel ballroom.

articles.headline: After Delay, KKR Finds a Way to Go Public
articles.snippet: The plan would value Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the storied private equity firm, at $12 billion to $15 billion.
articles.abstract: The plan would value Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the storied private equity firm, at $12 billion to $15 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the storied private equity firm, is again preparing to become a public company on the New York Stock Exchange, the firm said Sunday.

articles.headline: Fuel Subsidies Overseas Take a Toll on U.S.
articles.snippet: To understand why fuel prices in the U.S. have soared over the last year, it helps to get an idea of how foreign governments are subsidizing energy prices.
articles.abstract: To understand why fuel prices in the U.S. have soared over the last year, it helps to get an idea of how foreign governments are subsidizing energy prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia  To understand why fuel prices in the United States have soared over the last year, it helps to talk to the captain of a battered wooden freighter here.

articles.headline: A Media Powerhouse Everyone and Nobody Knows
articles.snippet: Aviv Nevo took a modest inheritance and parlayed it into a fortune by investing in media and Internet companies.
articles.abstract: Aviv Nevo took a modest inheritance and parlayed it into a fortune by investing in media and Internet companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the Fourth of July weekend at the billionaire Ronald O. Perelman’s 57-acre East Hampton estate the Creeks, Vivi Nevo was in his element.

articles.headline: Sudan Rallies Behind Leader Reviled Abroad
articles.snippet: Even the enemies of Sudan’s President Omar Hassan al-Bashir have closed ranks behind him, driven by national pride and a fear of chaos if he were removed.
articles.abstract: Even the enemies of Sudan’s President Omar Hassan al-Bashir have closed ranks behind him, driven by national pride and a fear of chaos if he were removed.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan  President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan has been accused by the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court of genocide and vilified the world over as an incorrigible mass murderer bent on slaughtering his own people in Darfur.
articles.byline: By Lydia Polgreen and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: In Volatile Times, Investors Tune in All and Any Predictions
articles.snippet: Amid a financial crisis where the unthinkable has become routine, Wall Street is struggling to get a handle on what will happen next.
articles.abstract: Amid a financial crisis where the unthinkable has become routine, Wall Street is struggling to get a handle on what will happen next.
articles.lead_paragraph: The news hit Wall Street trading floors on the morning of July 2: Some analyst at Merrill Lynch was saying the General Motors Corporation might go bankrupt.
